thread.title: Broncos continue pursuit of volleyball sectional title
thread.title_full: Broncos continue pursuit of volleyball sectional title

author: Mike Battreall The Herald Bulletin
title: Broncos continue pursuit of volleyball sectional title
text:
Broncos continue pursuit of volleyball sectional title By Mike Battreall The Herald Bulletin Herald Bulletin 
COWAN -- Daleville continued its bid for its first volleyball sectional championship in 16 years Saturday afternoon. 
Liberty Christian, however, will have to try again next October for a maiden sectional title. 
Class 1A No. 14 Daleville was pushed to five sets by a struggling Southern Wells squad in their Class 1A Sectional 55 semifinal before prevailing 25-15, 25-11, 24-26, 22-25, 15-7. 
The Broncos took a 19-10 record into Saturday night's final against Cowan, which eliminated LC 25-14, 25-21, 25-21. 
Daleville was cruising along to an apparent romp and had a 12-4 lead in the third set before the Raiders (8-25) knotted it at 19 and then saved three match points and won the final five points of the set. 
Southern Wells jumped ahead 16-6 in the fourth set, but front-liners Breanna Townsend and Lindsay Ingenito helped spark the Broncos to within 23-20 with three kills each. 
The Raiders were able to force a deciding set, but two kills and a block by Ingenito gave Daleville a 5-1 edge in set 5. 
Daleville never trailed by fewer than 5-3, as Townsend made the final three of her 13 kills down the stretch. Jennifer Shellabarger closed it out with a tip over the defense. 
"We have to battle a lot of times to play to win rather than to play not to lose," Broncos' coach Beth Etchison said. "I think they got those first two sets rather easily and they played complacent and decided to defend rather than to go on the offensive." 
Ingenito finished with 21 kills and 19 digs, and Zannah Weber had 43 assists, 18 digs and eight aces. 
"Having Lindsay's leadership on the court is something that we have to have at all times," said Etchison of Ingenito, a sophomore middle hitter. 
LC (8-19) took a six-match winless streak into its match and that coincided with a shoulder injury sustained by starting middle hitter Monica Watkins, which also kept her out Saturday. 
"When Monica went out, it threw us (off) a little bit," Lions' coach Mike Carey said. "She's such a dynamic player, but when you lose a player like that, it's like, 'How do you fill that gap?'" 
The Lions' other middle hitter, Melody Davidson, helped pick up the slack with 11 kills and three blocks. 
Cowan (9-19 going into the final) erased a 3-1 first-set deficit with six straight points and went on an 8-1 run to extend the lead to 17-9. 
LC, and especially Davidson, came to life in set 2. The 6-foot-1 junior had six kills and a block as the Lions dug out of a 4-0 hole and jumped ahead 10-7. The Lions built it to eight on three occasions (16-8 and 18-10 on kills by Savannah Rees, and 17-9). 
But a series of hitting errors and violations enabled Cowan to tie at 20, and an ace by Diana Campbell put the Blackhawks up 21-20. Cowan won the last four points of that set. 
The Lions faced another uphill climb in the final set, as the closest they got was ties at 1 and 4. LC made a mini-run near the end, postponing Cowan match points four times with Jenna Scott serving. 
"(Cowan's) going to be tough playing on their home court," Carey said. "But overall, I thought (we) played competitively and did a good job." 
Macy McFall contributed nine kills for the Lions, including five in the third set. 
Five LC seniors will depart the program -- Brooklynne Rees, Elizabeth Lane, Justice Clem, Danielle Johnson and Sierra Edwards. Sign Up / Sign In With your existing account from... {* loginWidget *}
